title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care services. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with various health conditions, including children with chronic illnesses and disabilities, those living with relatives due to parental incapacity, and individuals with mental retardation or developmental disabilities. Additionally, a significant portion of the elderly population experiences multiple chronic disabling conditions. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home annually, relying on extensive family caregiving before their deaths. 42 percent of individuals needing daily assistance in the US are under 65, with insufficient resources to replace family caregivers with paid workers. The cost of replacing family caregivers with paid services would be around $200 billion yearly. Family caregivers, mainly women, face emotional, physical, and financial hardships, often struggling to find information on available respite care programs. The text discusses the insufficiency of available respite care programs for family caregivers, particularly those caring for the elderly. The purpose of the title is to encourage the establishment of state and local respite care programs, improve information dissemination to caregivers, and enhance respite care services. It aims to promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery, worker recruitment, and caregiver training. The text discusses the need for training programs for family caregivers to make informed decisions about respite care services. It also mentions supporting research to identify effective respite care services and promoting the dissemination of results and findings related to respite care delivery and caregiver training. "SEC. 2802. DEFINITIONS." The term 'condition' includes various health and developmental issues such as Alzheimer's disease, physical disabilities, chronic illness, and cognitive impairments. An 'eligible recipient' refers to a State agency or any other public entity capable of receiving assistance. The term 'family caregiver' refers to an unpaid family member, foster parent, or another unpaid adult providing in-home care for a child or adult with special needs. Eligible recipients of assistance include public entities, nonprofit organizations, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000, and recognized State respite coordinating agencies with demonstrated abilities in respite care and family caregiver issues. The term 'lifespan respite care' refers to a system of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs, regardless of age or other factors. Respite care provides temporary relief to family caregivers when they are unable to provide care for individuals with special needs. The term 'special need' refers to the particular needs of individuals who require care or supervision due to a condition to meet their basic needs or prevent harm. "SEC. 2803. Lifespan respite care grants and cooperative agreements." The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. Coordination of respite care services across different agencies is emphasized. Application procedures are outlined for potential recipients. The section outlines the application process for eligible recipients seeking grants for respite care services. Applicants must demonstrate understanding of respite care, involve family members, caregivers, and collaborate with other agencies. The curr_chunk provides details on the population, respite care needs, existing services, coordination methods, and recruitment/training programs for respite care workers and volunteers. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for programs assisting family caregivers in decision-making about respite care services, including collaboration with other services and involvement of relevant agencies and populations. It emphasizes maximizing the use of Federal, State, and local resources. The curr_chunk details the criteria for identifying eligible family caregivers for respite care services and how the quality and safety of these services will be monitored. It also includes information on improving the coordination and distribution of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. The curr_chunk outlines the necessary skills for respite care, expected results, and confidentiality assurances. The Secretary will establish a panel to review applications and make recommendations. The Secretary will award grants or cooperative agreements based on panel recommendations, prioritizing applicants focusing on lifespan respite care. Recipients must use funds for developing respite care at state and local levels and providing services to address unmet needs. The Secretary awards grants for respite care services, including worker training and program evaluation. Recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies. Grants last up to 5 years and can be renewed. Funds must supplement, not replace, other sources for respite care. The Secretary shall establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care to maintain a national database, provide training and technical assistance, and offer information and educational programs to the public. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this title.
